title: New Zealand will create a unit to investigate terrorist content online
text:
The government will spend about $14 million over four years and hire 17 full-time staff to work with online content hosts to identify and thwart violent extremist content. The resources will help double the government’s investigative work in the area. (The Guardian)

Talking point: The effort is part of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern’s Christchurch Call, a global crisis-response framework to eliminate online terrorist and extremist content that came seven months after the worst mass shooting in the country’s history was livestreamed on Facebook and shared on Twitter, YouTube, WhatsApp and Instagram. Fifty companies and countries, including Canada, have signed on. New Zealand’s sovereign wealth fund launched its own initiative, in which financial institutions have put pressure on tech companies to cull hateful online content. Last week, a gunman livestreamed an attack on a German synagogue on Amazon’s Twitch. Amazon, which joined the Christchurch Call two weeks earlier, was able to use the initiative’s crisis-response tools to limit the video’s spread, said Ardern.
